speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Georgina
text: And I’m Georgina.

speaker: Neil
text: Now, Georgina, what do you know about AC DC?

speaker: Georgina
text: You mean the Australian rock’n’roll band? Well, their 1979 hit ‘Highway to Hell’ stayed at No.1 for eleven weeks…

speaker: Neil
text: No, no, no - not that AC DC, Georgina! I’m not talking rock music here, I’m talking electrical currents – alternating current - AC, and direct current - DC, the two ways in which electricity flows.

speaker: Georgina
text: Oh, I see. No, I don’t know anything about that ACDC!

speaker: Neil
text: Well, don’t worry because in today’s programme we’ll be finding out some quirky facts about electricity - how it differs across the world and why some countries have more complicated electrical systems than others.

speaker: Georgina
text: Hmmm, I have noticed that when I travel to another country I need a converter plug to connect my laptop. Is that something to do with AC DC?

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, it could be. Of course, electricity itself doesn’t change from country to country.

speaker: Georgina
text: No. It’s an invisible, natural force at work in everything from lightning storms to the electrical sparks firing our brains.

speaker: Neil
text: But although it happens naturally, one scientist was credited with discovering electricity. Who? That’s my quiz question – who discovered electricity? Was it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) Thomas Edison

speaker: Neil
text: b) Alexander Graham Bell, or

speaker: Neil
text: c) Benjamin Franklin

speaker: Georgina
text: I’m not a qualified electrician myself, Neil, but I’ll say c) Benjamin Franklin.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. Well one person who definitely is a qualified electrician is BBC presenter Gareth Mitchell. So when BBC Radio 4’s ‘Science Stories’ sent him to meet electricity expert Keith Bell, the conversation was, shall we say, sparky.

speaker: frequencysynchronous
text: Standard frequency in the US is 60 hertz, actually I think in the US on the mainland US, main continent, there are three different synchronous areas. So although it’s around 60 hertz, at any moment in time these three different areas, because they’re not connected to each other, will be going at a slightly different frequency. There are bigger differences elsewhere. So in Japan for example, I think one of the main islands is at 60 hertz and the other half of Japan is at 50 hertz.

speaker: a bit of a pickle!
text: That’s a bit of a pickle!

speaker: Neil
text: Generally speaking, frequency means how often something repeats. In the case of electrical currents, frequency is the number of times an electrical wave repeats a positive-to-negative cycle.

speaker: Georgina
text: It’s measured in hertz (Hz). In the US power is at 60 hertz and in the UK it’s around 50 hertz.

speaker: Neil
text: So the US and UK are not in the same synchronous area – not occurring together at the same time and rate, or in this case, frequency.

speaker: Georgina
text: Which means that to safely use a British electrical device in America, I need to convert the power supply. If not it won’t work or even worse, it could break.

speaker: Neil
text: And a broken laptop could leave you in a bit of a pickle – an informal expression meaning a difficult situation with no obvious answer. Here’s Gareth and Keith again talking about more differences.

speaker: charge upanomalies
text: I’m pretty sure when I go to the United States, my electric toothbrush doesn’t charge up at 60 hertz - 110 volts, but my laptop still works. Maybe you have no comment, Keith, but I’m just saying…one of these anomalies that I seem to have found.

speaker: solid state
text: So, I’m not sure about the electric toothbrush but I know a lot of our power supplies for laptops and stuff are solid state, you know - they’ve got electronics in that do all the conversion for you, so basically it ends up with a DC supply into the machine itself. So there’s a little converter in there and it’s designed so it doesn’t care what frequency the AC input is.

speaker: Neil
text: Gareth noticed that in the United States his toothbrush doesn’t always fully charge up – get the power needed to make it work.

speaker: Georgina
text: Electric toothbrushes which don’t fully charge and differences between electrical frequencies are good examples of anomalies – things which are different from what is usual or expected.

speaker: Neil
text: But with modern technology these anomalies are becoming less and less commonplace. For example, computer companies have started making laptops with solid state electronics – electronics using semiconductors which have no moving parts and can automatically convert different electrical currents.

speaker: Georgina
text: Meaning I can use my laptop to google the answer to your quiz question!

speaker: Neil
text: Ah, yes. I asked you which scientist was credited with discovering electricity. And you said?

speaker: Georgina
text: c) Benjamin Franklin – and I already know I’m right because I googled it on my solid state laptop! To show that lightning was electricity, Franklin attached a metal key to a kite and flew it during a thunderstorm. The key conducted electricity and gave him a shock!

speaker: anomalies
text: Hmm, not an experiment I recommend trying at home! Today we’ve been talking about anomalies – or unexpected differences in electrical currents between countries.

speaker: frequenciessynchronous
text: Electrical currents are measured in frequencies – the number of times a wave repeats a positive-to-negative cycle. These can be different if two countries are not synchronous – occurring at the same rate, for example Britain and the United States.

speaker: frequenciescharge up
text: Different frequencies may mean your electrical devices like your laptop, phone and toothbrush won’t properly charge up – get the power to function, in other countries.

speaker: in a bit of a pickle
text: And having a phone with no power could leave you in a bit of a pickle - a difficult situation.

speaker: solid state
text: Fortunately many modern devices use solid state electronics – non-moving semiconductors inside the machine which automatically convert the electrical current.

speaker: Georgina
text: So you’ll never miss another edition of 6 Minute English again!

speaker: Neil
text: That’s all for today. See you soon at BBC Learning English for more interesting topics and related vocabulary. Bye for now!

speaker: Georgina
text: Bye!
